text: From the tap at FOB, Rimini, Italy. Pours intense gold with looots of white fluffy foam. Took several attempts to draft it. Aroma is a very nice mix of citrus and floral, scarcely persistent. It becomes more herbaceous over time. Body is medium-dense. Taste is markedly bitter. Final is long and bitter, herbaceous.
On tap at Free House Brewery in Trieste. pours deep gold. Almost no aroma. Sweet taste with dry final.
Hazy golden with a small white head. Fruity and floral hop aroma with a touch of malt. Sweetish fruity flavour with malty and grassy notes. Quite bitter finish.

Grain and cereal malts, light bread, caramel, sweet citrus fruits, orange peel. Clear gold, small, creamy, white head. Light bitter. More grain and cereal malts, bitter citrus fruits, grapefruit, straw, grass, soft carbonation, light bodied, dry and bitter finish. Nice Bitter, well-balanced, quite rich. Cask at The Marble Arch, Manchester.

Bottle from Alesbymail. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, light nutty and light hoppy - flowers. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 160417

A traditional bitter that is smooth and quaffable with the hint of an exotic hop but not too much. Had this at the Marble Arch Manchester and was very impressed with this new take on a traditional flavour.

Clear copperish-brown with creamy head. Aroma of light caramel and fruity esters, with herbal notes. Taste nutty, light caramel, some bitterness. Simple with a bit of a rough edge, kinda like its namesake.
End of a cask at 57, Manchester. Opaque brownish, aroma of peach, Jasmin, yogurt. Moving. Taste that makes me think of a barley wine, with some thick slick sugar.
Cask at the hanging bat. Pours clear golden, nose is sweet toffee, caramel, little buttery, taste is similar, floral, sickly.
Goudblond bier met wandklevend wit schuim. Geur: hoppig, grassig, fruitig, mandarijn. Smaak: fruitig, zoetig, bitter. Afdronk: droog bitter. Aangename dorstlesser.

bitter al limite della perfezione del classico stile britannico.
leggermente più schiumosa delle classiche bitter ma aroma,aspetto e gusto perfetti !

Bottle. Hazy golden head with a medium white head. Lively fizz. Good lacing. Aroma of herbs, melon rind and lime pith. Flavour of weak tea, wood, grass and a bitter finish. Thin to medium body with a light, fizzy mouthfeel. Well balanced and quite hoppy for a Bitter.

Bright clear orange-copper colour with a frothy white head and good lacings. Noses of biscuity toffee notes with a light floral touch. Soft carbonation, lightly slick with a light body. Brisk sweetness and faintly bitter. Short finish. Enjoyable session beer.
bottle. Clear yellow with small white head. Floral hoppy butter aroma. Bitter flavour with salty notes

Very pale golden, decent white and lasting white cap. Nose is super grainy, seedy and a long throw of copper and lemon. Initial taste is clean enough, steely grainy bitterness quickly seeks out any flavour and squashes it. Firm carbonation, clean and lightly creamy mouthfeel. Finishes a lean starchy bitter, lingers soft gritty lemon. Clean and sessionable if devoid of flavour or any real enjoyment. Bottle, Ninas Mini Market, Edinburgh

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ loft, mcr airportclear bright gold with soft white head. Dry dusty grain sack nose, cereal notes up first then gentle citrus & digestive biscuit malt. Medium body, light carbonation, fruity finish.
Cask. Pours clear golden with white head. Aroma is light hops, many apples, biscuit, fruity and caramel. Taste is quite fruity, red apples, biscuit, light bitter with light malty finish. Crisp.

Hand Pump at 4:20 in Rome-Italy. Pours and hazy golden color, tick creamy cap. Nose: dusty, bottom yeast, a bit of butter. Mouth: malt rich feel, yeast, citric bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Spina @ fob.
Chiara con schiuma fine e persistente.
Amara, corpo leggero, bella secca, astringe un pelo.
Ottima  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Mi4i

Cask at The Earl Grey Inn, Leek. A clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma of fruity malt, lemon, boiled sweets, some caramel and floral hops. Taste of fruity malt, some cranberry, lemon, slight caramel and floral hops. Light bodied and a smooth texture. A fruity, floral bitterness in the finish. A smooth, easy drinking bitter with a good amount of floral hops and fruity malt. Simple but nice.

Handpump @Ma che siete venuti a fà (Rome). Pours golden with a medium white head. Aroma is malty with a gentle hops bouquet, grass, light citrus and floral, nice. Flavour is balanced between malt and bitter, good. Light body, light carbonation. Well done!
A pompa a scurreria beer&bagel ..Fantastica ! A pompa è veramente la morte sua .. Tutto il classico inglese sul malto delle bitter vecchia maniera .. Luppolatura seria inglese .. Old empire !
Cask, hand-pulled, State Bar, weak pale malt aroma, clear golden, bubbly white head, good lacing, earthy, malty, very easy to drink, well balanced, satisfying

From cask at The Grain Loft, Manchester Airport, 11.05.15. Clear, pale golden. Dense, even and persistent off-white head and lacing. Aroma and taste of pale malt, with refined bitterness. Decent bitterness in aftertaste.

Aroma: malty, caramel, herbs, esters.
Appearance: hazy golden color, nice white head.
Taste: medium bitterness (herbs, slightly stalky), flower notes, roasted caramel, malty, quite dry and maybe a little bit watery.
Palate: low body and high carbonation, bitter finish.
Overall: Really good bitter, bitterness is slightly stalky.
Yellow colour. Light grass and apple in the aroma. Light malts, slightly nutty. Dry finish. Creamy texture.

Aroma is biscuity pale malts, small caramel note, grassy, earthy peppery English hop. Taste is well balanced, its like the classic bitter, its a superb beer shame its from Manchester ! highly recommend this to anyone with a taste for fine beer
Recht fluffig und frisch mit einer netten Mischung aus Hopfen und Hefe. Daneben recht fruchtige Noten und eine angenehme Spritzigkeit. Vollkommen in Ordnung.

Bottle from niquillis - many thanks! The beer has got a clear golden -strawy colour with a low head and medium body. Aroma of bitterness and citrus fruits. Taste of hops, bread, grass, citrus fruits and light malt. Hints of grains and herbs. Easy to drink, quite bitter, with a refreshing touch. Solid beer.

Cask at CPK, London. It pours a clean golden amber color with a small white head. Aroma is mild caramel, dried leaves, grass, bread, earth. Taste is medium sweet and light citrusy, with notes of bread, grass, caramel. Overall, ok bitter
Cask at CASK in Pimlico. Light, dry hops with a bitter finish and a hint of citrus. Nothing too complex but beautifully balanced and incredibly drinkable.

Exciting bubblegum / lemon aroma.
Lovely citrus hoppy flavor ..
Good easy-drinking beer.
Beautiful golden color tightly White blanket of foam.

500ml bottle.
Pours a medium straw, with a white head.
Malty, fairly hoppy aroma, citrus, resin, wood (!), yeast, pine.
Dry, light to medium bodied, mid bitterness, slightly low CO2.
Malty, spicy, quite robust taste, hops, grapefruit, earth, grass.
Finishes faintly harsh, with a lightly sour note. Decent. (2014-07-04)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at the Euston Tap, 24/06/14.
Clear golden with a moderate off white covering that retains.
Nose is orchard fruit twinges, bready pangs, apple skin, light smoke, biscuit crumble, lemon curd.
Taste comprises bready malt, apple orchard, light floral bitterness, woody rinse.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light bitterness in the close.
Decent enough golden bitter.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
cask at Bodega NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE
Yellowish beer with white head that dissipates quickly
malty aroma with fruity tones
taste is bitterish with fruit bit citrussy
decent beer
Cask (Fitzgeralds, Newcastle) - Golden with a white head. Lemon, grapefruit and peach in the aroma. Refreshing taste with notes of lemon, grapefruit and tea.

Cask west riding dewsbury. Clear yellow colour good white head and lacing. Aroma is popcorn malts. Taste is toffee popcorn sweet pale malts light hops mild bitter finish. Medium body soft carbonated. Session beer.
Cask @ Old Gate, Hebden Bridge. Golden-blonde with a smooth head. Dry hopped with a pale ale fruitiness evident and a medium-high bitterness.
Pint on cask at marble arch, Manchester. Pours to a very golden creamy colour and settles to a light golden session ale. Taste starts off smooth but aftertaste leaves slightly bitter finish
Flaske 0,5l drukket på rom 606 på Premier Inn Victoria, Manchester 27 Jan 13. Veldig lys gylden. Medium høyt skum. Beskjeden fruktaroma. Smaken er tung frukt. Tungdrikkelig. Svakt syrlig ettersmak,
Cask at Manchester Beer and Cider Festival 22/1/2014 Pours a pale colour, taste is light with some biscuits and cereal, overall good
Cask at old fountain. Very nice, just a classic, quite crisp bitter with sensible grain and malt in the body and some light citrus tang.
Bottle @ home. Pours golden with a big white head. Citrus fruits, pineapple to the front. Nice enough, nothing great.

Bottle from Bernies Real Ale Off Licence, Solihull. Poured a hazy medium amber with a big frothy white head. This beer had a lot of life. The aroma is of citrus fruit. The flavour is medium bitter, with lots of malt fruit and hoppy liqourice on the crisp refreshing palate. The bitterness lingers for a white in the finish. A super tasty session ale.
Tap at manchester airport. Clear golden color, smooth white head. Sweet malty aroma, honey, some fruits. Sweet and balanced malty taste, nicely hops and fruits. Best british bitter so far.

Cask at Southampton Arms. Very slightly hazy colour with thin white head. Not much in the way of aroma - a slightly chemical citrus scent, but its not offensive. Its light, a little citrussy, a little malty, with a bitter, ever so medicinal pepto bismol finish. It's OK. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ the Marble Arch in Manchester, my brother ordered it after getting tired of all the casks .. . hazy gold .. . medium foam .. . mild hops .. pretty clean .. . low ballin .. . look at the label, manchester is red!! .. . . take your pants off! ..no im kidding, what are you? weird or something!?!
On cask at The Holy Inadequate, Etruria.  Pours golden with white head.  Quite fruity with a hop tang.  Enjoyable enough.
cask, Knott Bar, Manchester. Floral and fragrant pale bitter, with a bit of cherry in there somewhere. Clean palate with faint raspberry hints and a short bittersweet aftertaste.
500ml bottle - Golden coloured with a hazy appearance, mad frothy white head. Some sour fruit flavour. Bitter slightly dry finish. Not bad, but nowhere near as good as any of the other Marble beers.
Half Pint at the National Winter Ales Festival in Manchester.  Cloudy and pale with little head.  Light fruity bitter aroma.  Sharp and bitter taste, dry and fruity.  Decent for a bitter.
Hand pulled at Dean Swift, London.  Golden ale with a nicely balanced bittersweet hoppyness.  Floral hops finish.  Light aroma.  Not outstanding but perfectly drinkable.

Bottle. What a boring name for an excellent beer.Golden and hoppy with a small head and slightly dry finnish.Low carbonation and excellently bottled. I am not a great bitter fan but this is a top grade beer no matter how you look at it.

Bottle. Pours cloudy amber, bubbly with strong head. Bitter lemon and wheaty hops taste. Palate of white bread, smooths off. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Arch Inn. 
Golden clear body, filmy layer. Grain, citrus notes and bitterness to the nose. Orange/tangerines and sunflower in addition to a lasting bitterness. A true bitter! (5.Jul.2012)

([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Arms, SE London) Pours pale yellow with a medium white head. small, good lacing and medium to light in body. Aroma is citrus hops and malt. Taste is very nice citrus caramel malt blend. Decent brew, very drinkable.

On tap @ Marble Arch. Pours golden with a thin but attractive head and a decent level of carbonation. The nose is clean and hoppy - going down the lemon to grapefruit line. The taste has more of the same with some pale malt in the background. The palate is very balanced - medium in body and texture with a clean but not overly bitter finish. Overall, very drinkable indeed.

Sample at marble inn.
Thick creamy white head.  Slightly hazy blond pour.  Nice bitterness.  Nice brew.

Cask in the Southampton Arms. Yes, this is a Manchester bitter, I can hear my dad wittering on about how Bods used to have a really good smack to it (but that was in the 60s/70s, a bit more than 20 years ago). And here we have a pale golden bitter, austere malty dryness, bitter hop finish, supremely moreish and drinkable. Local bias perhaps but this stuff is awesome.
Bottle.  Floral citrus nose.  Well balanced bitterness, big grapefruit flavours. Feels a little like a wheat beer in the mouth. Will be buying more.

Handpull pint at Old Fountain.  Clear refractive gold with a solid one-finger white head.  Simple fresh cereal and herbal/floral dry bitterness in aroma and taste - some alcohol, really well-balanced (thank you for no sweetness!).  Chewy, lightly astringent mouthfeel, decent body, longish non-aggressive dried flower bitter finish.  Nice.
Nice full flavour. Doesnt last. Smells malty but without much aroma. Quite good.

Bottle, The Beer Emporium, Sandbach. Pours a lovely golden colour, nice head that lasted down the glass. Aromas of citrus fruits, flavour of toffee, caramel with a good hoppy bitterness. Really enjoyed this beer and would seek out again.

really good bitter. lovely looking pint
a great subtle citrus flavour, mostly lemon pith. lots of bitterness in the finish, cracking!

ill hunt it down on draught.
bottle. pooky & grumps. leeds

Beautiful yet subtle pine hop aroma, a little woody. Taste is really well balanced. Soft tropical fruits from the hops and a lovely caramel malt finish. Some biscuit and cereal. Awesome mouthfeel. So drinkable. Im off behind the bar for another.

Cask in Euston Tap. Colour is very pale amber with white head. Nose is very fragrant citrous and touch of floral and tropical fruit. Getting a lot of pithy citrous juice and peel. Taste is light citrous, lots of husky grain malt, body is a touch watery, but very nice. Creamy head and finish is light citrous bitter.

Bottle. Golden with a white finger of fluff. Light nose of malts and grapefruit. Develops in the mouth and is surprisingly complex. Cereal malts, nuts, citrus, grapefruits and a mild banana. Light bitter finish making this extremely drinkable.
50cl, English brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex brew, bitter/fruity and slighly malty, refreshing, balanced, hazy, rocky head, nice brew

A - malt with light citrus
A - mid gold with thick head
T - light sweet with mid to full bitter
P - mid and soft
O - good, but not great
Cask at Market Porter, 20th October 2011.  Nice flavour above average bitter, would certainly try more of the Marble beers, have heard good things

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2012 Cask @ The Marble Arch Inn, Manchester. 071011 Light straw, frothy white head. Aroma of light grassy hops. Taste - light malt, light grass and citrus hops. Palate - very low carb, thin texture, slightly powdery. Finish is very light grassy bitter that dissipates quickly. They were selling a lot of this while I was here (bland beer is more popular I suppose). Itâs quite nice, better than average but itâs a bit bland (I did have the Dobber just before!) - not much going on here. Marble do much better beers.
 Re-rate: Brandling Arms, South Gosforth - Certainly not bland much more grassy / citrusy hops on this re-try. Still not mad keen on this though but it is pretty good

50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via The Dram Shop. Pale golden, very nice aroma of a nutty citrus infused spice. A lot of flavour for a 4% ale, nuttiness and bright hops. Medium body, could stand up to some of the more imperial of IPAs. Long bitter finish.
Golden with fine white head, malt, lemon and hops nose,  crisp and bitter tangy palate with faint floral notes, very tasty.
In bottle. Light yellow beer with a thick white head. Passionfruit and pineapple aroma. Tastes fruity with a lingering bitterness. Very nice session beer.

Cask at the Marble Meet the Brewer event at the CASK, Pimlico, 8th Sept 2010. Clear gold. Quite light palate. Bland but drinkable session bitter. Nothing wrong with it but there are many much better beers available from Marble.
Cask at Euston Tap. Pale golden beer, small creamy offwhite head. Fruity citrus flavor, hoppy, grassy with some perfume. Malty citrus flavor with bready notes. Long perfume and pepper finish.

Cask. Golden yellow doby, white head. Aroma has loads of english hops, fruitiness and yoghurt, peach and mango, bisquit malt. Flavour is big with really nice hops, some lactic sourness and bitterness. Toasty malty backbone. Very nice smoothness.

Cask, 4.2% at the brewpub. Fruity berry aroma. Clear yellow colour. Stable creamy chalk white head. The flavour starts off teaish, turning more fruity later. Medium bitterness, very clean. Good, but perhaps too clean.

(Cask at Gallows Real Ale Festival 2011) The beer poured pale golden and bit muddy. No head. Aroma contained fruitiness, hops and toffee. Palate was medium bodied and dry. Flavours were malts, hops, fruitiness, mustiness and bitterness. Aftertaste was bitter. A bit too musty brew for my taste. Aroma was good.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2011 Cask at the Gallows Bird, Espoo, Finland. XIV Real Ale Festival.
Clear pale golden colour with tiny frothy head.
Quite strong fruity bitter hoppiness in aroma.
Nice combination of fruity hops, malty body and caramel. Balanced.
Mild hoppynose with blackcurrant notes. Pale thin head. Pale golden colour. Low carbonation. Mild hoppy taste. Hoppy bitterness at end.

Funny. I did not know this was intended to recreate the Boddingtons. I had that on cask in Chinatown, Manchester just about 20 years ago, and it was an excellent beer.
This is a bitter in every sense of the word, Id say it appeals to more experienced palates. An English session beer with an extra load of hops. This could be consumed in large quantities. A countryside pub garden with this on cask would be heavenly.

0.5L bottle [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, London. Tall and foamy snowy white head. Hazed, shimmering yellow body. Dough and white bread on the nose. Also a whiff of grassy/hayish hops. Taste is fairly dry with a clean, doughy and bready malt base. Grassy and faint citrussy hops in the backbone. Light-bodied without being thin. Quite fizzy in the mouth. Short,  but fresh and dry ending.

Cask conditioned	air dispense	Euston Tap	London.  A golden beer with a big white head.  A devilishly lively pour to this beer with a suggestion of shallowing.  Hops are present but not massive.  Theres a subtle lemon flavour.  Its OK but needs balls.  I drank Boddingtons over 20 years ago when it was an indepenant brewery and I have to say my memories of it are better than my experience today.

Cask at the Euston Tap. Pours clear yellow with a mild, white head. Doughy malts on the nose with some citrus and straw hops. Lightly sweet with modest, tart citrus and straw bitterness. Light in body with fine, creamy carbonation. Finishes with faint sweetness and lingering earth and resinous hops. Picks up speed late. Pretty good.

From cask at the brewpub. Pours clear and pale yellow with a small, creamy, lacing and white head. Aroma  is crisp citrusy hoppy, light grassy touch. Citrusy and bitter flavoured, subdued sweetness. Ends crisp bitter and citrusy fruity.

Cask (gravity) - Norwich Beer Festival 2010. Pours with a head typical of gravicask: fluffy, bubbly & lasting, white in colour with a delicately hazy gold body. Brilliant, crisp grapefruit & lemon hop aroma. Crisp hop flavour profile: lemon, a bit of sherbet with a lingering finish. Light, drinkable body (and I could easily have gone for more), light to medium carbonation and a decent length end. A really lovely, straight up but standout bitter.

500ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy golden with a medium head.  Aroma is pineapple and piney hops.  Tropical fruits to start and a nice piney hoppy finish with medium bitterness.  Drinks above its strength.  Very impressed.
Bottle from Utobeer Market Stall. Light yellow pour with a white head. Light spice nose. Citrus and herb aromas. Fresh hop taste with a hint of pineapple and herbs. Light hop finish. Dry.
Cask at the CASK Pub & Kitchen, London during Meet the Brewer on 8th September 2010. Gold with thin white part-lacing head. Light and hoppy, rounded, and with a citric finish. Light mouthfeel.

8th September 2010. Cask Pub & Kitchen. Meet The Brewer  Thanks to Ethereal for the half pint! Cheers Casper! Clear pale gold beer with a residual suddy head. Light semi dry palate. Sweetish banana cream base for a little citric hop. Nice! Finishes dry.

Cask (@ Kings Arms, Hawkshead): Yellow coloured with a smaller white head; distinctive hoppy-lemony nose; light bodied, moderate to robust bitter-sweet flavour; dry lingering aromatic hoppy finish. Superb......
chiara poca schiuma naso luppoato citrico un tocco agrumato in bocca pulita agrumata buon amaro

(Old BA rate - cask)
Yellowy gold, and hinging on amber as well. Thin, white head poured at the perfect height. Fantastic lacing all throughout the sample. roma is light, citrusy and bitter hop aroma that was followed by biscuity maltiness. Brilliant hop bitterness up front with a dry floral finish. A lot creamier than I expected for the style. Very full mouthfeel with a decent coating of the tongue. This would do me great all night long. Lighter body might have been nice, but I cant complain with all of the great flavors going on. What a treat, and at such a reasonable abv. Overall, this is a great interpretation and update of a very traditional style. Well-done, and I can see why it was the most popular beer at the pub.

Cask at the Marble Arch. Light amber color, but amazingly full flavored. Fruity, rounded, with a little citrus. Great hops, but with excellent balance and a slight bubblegum hint as well. A truly great bitter--surely one of the most impressive I can remember, and in tip-top shape at the brewpub.

As cask beers go, this is one of the best pints Ive had in a long time. Marble are a great brewery and they deserve being shouted about. As a best bitter this kicks ass with fruity hops and awesome drinkability. More British cask beer should taste like this.

Cask @ Woking Beer Festival 2009. Pours a yellowy gold colour with a thin, white head. Light, citrusy and bitter hop aroma that was followed by biscuity maltiness. The flavour is hop bitterness up front with a dry floral finish. Very enjoyable beer.

Gravicask from Bar Unusuale at GBBF 09. Clear golden body topped by a bubbly ring. Floral hoppy to the nose. Fresh fruity taste progressing to a pleasant bittersweet finish. Typical for the style and just alright to drink (London,05.08.2009).
[RBESG 2009].Cask (handpump) @ Marble Arch Inn. Light amber color. Flowery hops with some fruit notes. Quite light and esy drinking.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is mild floral hoppy notes along with some caramel. Flavour is quite much the same with some slight sappy notes.

[cask @ RBESG 2009]
Creamy but weak UK hops aroma with very low citrus notes. Almost clear gold under lasting shaving foam. Crisp base malt flavour with some lemony hops and a moderate bitterness. Light to medium body, low carbonation, moderately bitter finish.
Cask (handpump) @ Marble Arch Inn, 73 Rochdale Rd, Manchester, Greater Manchester England M4 4HY... golden amber ... light fruity hop ... watery and light ... little mellon... lotsof hop.

[RBESG, Sheffield]
Cask @ Marble Arch, Manchester.
Pours clear golden with a small, frothy, off-white film head. Aroma is lightly sweet, some pine and sweet bready malts. A bit of honey. Low carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour is sweet, fat bready malts, light pine and a good, dry bitter finish. Very good bitter.

Cask handpull, Marble Arch, Manchester, RBESG 09.  Gold, lasting beige head.  Lovely grapefruity aroma.  Creamy and full in mouth, some malt.  Hoppy finish.  Excellent.  Had a few pints of this including with dinner, just because it was so drinkable.
Cask @ Marble Arch Manchester. Golden color. Malty, flowery and earthy hopbitter flavor. Just a hint of chloride and salt. Chloride aroma.

Cask @ National Winter Ales Festival 2009, Manchester. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty floral hoppy aroma. Slightly sweetish malty hoppy flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a fruity malty hoppy finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Cask-conditioned at the Marble Arch, Manchester 10/06/09. Golden in colour with a lacy white head. Aroma of green tea, hay and lychee aroma. Easy drinking with some sweetish biscuit malts, tropical fruit and a short, bitter finish. Good.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 The Knott, Manchester. Pale lagery looks. Muted butter and odd sweet Strawberry Chewit and fern aroma. Rattle of overhead train, Tom waits rasping on the box, chlorophyll reinforcement. Sickly strange and medicinal with cherry, hay, and vanilla. Long sweet biscuit. Needs a bit of warming up. Dried apricot/hairy citrus. Not enough bite for me. Sweet and weird.

Cask in Blackfriars. Aroma is biscuity pale malts, small caramel note, grassy, earthy peppery english hop. Taste is soo well balanced, its like the classic bitter, its awsome so i got ruined on it while i was working.

Cask (handpump) @ Marble Arch, Manchester M4, UK. Clear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate hoppy, flowers, toffee, butter. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to light, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft - flat. (180108)

A Mes rate: Cask at the Marble Arch Inn.Nice gold colour with a good white head. Very grassy green hoppage in the nose with a slight sweetness from the malt. Straight forward malt and hop flavour. Slight tea, light tobacco notes and a nice creamy bitter finish. Beats Boddys for sure if you ask me.

[CASK: The Lass-O-Gowry, Manchester 18/02/07] A poor bitter and definatly doesnt live up to its name. Manchester is a city of good ales and this is a most dissapointment! Dont bother to try you will just be let down.

(Cask at Marble Arch, Manchester, 27 July) Colour is golden yellow with frothy white head. Nose is fruity and hoppy with notes of spices, hay, pineapple and lemon. Taste is fruity with a nice spicy, floral hop character and notes of tropical fruit (pineapple). Rather dry and slightly metallic finish. Complex and very nice stuff.

Pale yellow, good white head. Very fresh cut grass and flowery hoppy nose. Lemony, fruity, bitter with long hoppy aftertaste. Refreshing and solid.

1. Cask Handpump at the Bar Fringe, Manchester 24/01/2002
Golden coloured and pale with some wheat flavour. Slightly bitter hop finish.
2. Cask Handpump at the Marble Arch Inn, Manchester 24/08/2002
Clear golden and very hoppy. Pale with a slightly bitter finish.

[Cask at GBBF 2005] A hazy orange beer with an off-white head. The aroma is sweet hoppy with a light buttery notes to it too. The flavor is slighlty buttery combined with a good hop presence, leading to a dry bitter end. The body is thin. Im wondering, if the butter is supposed to be there?

Cask conditioned, GBBF 2005:
Butter aroma. Woods in the flavour. Bitter finish with a touch of oak.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 Cask, The Knott, Manchester.  Light gold with an off-white head.  Aromas are sweet and floral, buttery with lemon, dry with ginger (or is that a remnant of the Marble Ginger?).  Flavours are sweet caramel with citrus and peppery hops.  Peppery on the finish.  Decent bitter.  Bottle - well balanced with hints of lime and ginger.  Good stuff.
Hand pulled at the Wellington, Birmingham. Very clean, fresh and flavoursome Bitter. Some fruity citrus notes, some peppery bitterness and bite to the hop background. Excellent session material.

Fruity esters and herbal hops in the clean malt aroma.  Clear golden body with low off-white head that diminishes to cover.  Clean malt flavour with herbal hops, light fruitiness and light finishing bitterness.  Nicely balanced.  Medium body with fair carbonation.  Cask at GBBF 2005.

Cask (gravity dispense) at GBBF, August 2005. Didnt realise this was supposed to be a recreation of the old Boddies. Slightly clammy hop aroma. Flavour is fresh, clean and distinctly herbal. I certainly dont recall that in the old Boddies. Comparisons aside, this is a rather nice pint (or few sips from a shared glass in this case). Dry and moderately bitter.
Cask @ GBBF 2005: Golden coloured. Clear. Fluffy white head. Fruity and fresh aroma. Flavour of herbs and fruit with some flowery notes. Has a  clean and dry bitterness in the end. I quite like this.

Not too bad, but a slightly raw malt sweetness lets it down a bit. Sweetish and a little sticky, with some hop bitterness in the finish. A little dissapointing, but drinkable.

Cask in Marble, Manchester.  True, this was an attempt to recreate Boddies - but it doesnt taste much like the boddie I remember in 1988!  Too dark, and lacks the blackcurranty fruitiness boddies used to have.  Still, a very dry, tangy bitter beer in the NW England style.

Draft at the "knot the fringe" bar.
Pale gold, a tad cloudy. Not much aroma. Good tang of Target (?)hops. Fruity aftertaste. 
great session beer as Boddies used to be with a smidge of Holts thrown in.

Sampled cask conditioned at Marble Arch, Manchester.
Golden colour. Flowery nose. Smooth and very soft mouthfeel. Salty  and nicely bitter finish.

When I was doing my masters the public library in Halifax had a copy of the first ever Pocket Guide to Beer.  It was in the reference section, so I couldnt take it out.  I tried to steal it, but that didnt get very far.  One of the most interesting things about that first edition is that Boddingtons was rated ****1/2 out of five.  Today it gets * out of four.  What happened?  Big brewery magic.  Well, Marble Arch has decided to recreate the old Boddingtons, the one that only Mancunians would know about...here it is.  Pale, quite dry, lots of hops, but underlying as opposed to up front.  Good, quenching pint.
